Case 2:15-cv-01259-NVW   Document 173   Filed 04/05/16   Page 2 of 108
1 INTRODUCTION
2 1. Byhonoring the moral imperatives enshrined in our Constitution, this nation
3 has successfullyshed much of its historyof legallysanctioned discrimination on the basis 
4 of race or ethnicity. We have seen in vivid, shameful detail how separate treatment is 
5 inherentlyunequal. Brown v. Board of Education, 347 U.S. 483, 495 (1954). There can be 
6 no law under our Constitution that creates and applies pervasive separate and unequal 
7 treatment to individuals based on a quantum of blood tracing to a particular race or 
8 ethnicity. This country committed itself to that principle when it ratified the Fourteenth 
9 Amendment and overturned Dred Scott v. Sandford, 60 U.S. 393 (1857), and when it 
10 abandoned Plessy v. Ferguson, 163 U.S. 537 (1896).
11 2. In 1994 and again in 1996, Congress recognized that race and ethnicity
12 should play no role in state-approved adoptions when it enacted the Multiethnic Placement 
13 Act, Pub. L. 103-382, ยงยง 551โ553,  codified at 42  U.S.C.  ยง  5115a  (1994),  and  the 
14 Interethnic Placement Act, Pub. L. 104-188, ยง 1808, codified at 42 U.S.C. ยงยง 671(a), 
15 674(d),  1996b  (1996),  which  forbid  discrimination  in  adoptions  and  foster  care 
16 placements.
17 3. Children with Indian ancestry, however, are still living in the era of Plessy 
18 v. Ferguson. Alone among American children, their adoption and foster care placements
19 are determined not in accord with their best interests but bytheir ethnicity, as a result of a
20 well-intentioned but profoundlyflawed and unconstitutional federal law, the Indian Child
21 Welfare Act (โICWAโ), codified at 25 U.S.C. ยงยง 1901โ1963.
22 4. This civil rights class action is filed by Plaintiffs baby girl A.D., baby boy 
23 C.C., babygirl L.G.,and babyboyC.R., byCarol Coghlan Carterand Dr. Ronald Federici, 
24 their next friends, and S.H. and J.H., foster/adoptive parents of baby girl A.D., M.C. and 
25 K.C., adoptive parents of baby boy C.C., and P.R. and K.R., foster/adoptive parents of 
26 babygirl L.G. and baby boyC.R.They file this action on behalf of themselves and all off-
27 reservation  Arizona-resident  children  with  Indian  ancestry and  all  off-reservation 
28
2of 35

Case 2:15-cv-01259-NVW   Document 173   Filed 04/05/16   Page 3 of 108
1 Arizona-resident foster, preadoptive, and prospective adoptive parents in child custody 
2 proceedings involving children with Indian ancestry.
3 5.  They seek a declaration by this Court that certain provisions of ICWA, and 
4 Guidelines issued by the Bureau of Indian Affairs (BIA), both facially and as applied, 
5 violate the United States Constitution. Theyalso seek an injunction from this Court against 
6 the application of certain provisions of ICWA and the accompanying BIA Guidelines, and 
7 nominal damages under Title VI of the Civil Rights Act (42 U.S.C. ยง 2000dโ2000d-7).
8 JURISDICTION AND VENUE
9 6.  This Court has subject matter jurisdiction under 28 U.S.C. ยง 1331.
10 7.  This Court is authorized to grant declaratory and injunctive relief under 5 
11 U.S.C. ยงยง 701 through 706, 28 U.S.C. ยงยง 2201 and 2202, 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983, Federal Rules 
12 of Civil Procedure (โFRCPโ) 57 and 65, and by the general and equitable powers of the 
13 federal judiciary. This Court is authorized to grant nominal damages, and declaratoryand 
14 injunctive relief under Title VI of the Civil Rights Act (42 U.S.C. ยงยง 2000dโ2000d-7).
15 8.  Venue is proper under 28 U.S.C. ยง 1391(b), (e).
16 PARTIES
17 9.  Plaintiff A.D. is a citizen of the United States and the State of Arizona, and 
18 domiciled in the State of Arizona. Baby girl A.D. is approximately 1 year and 6 months 
19 old. Baby girl A.D. is an enrolled member of the Gila River Indian Community, a 
20 federally-recognized  tribe.  Parental  rights  of  A.D.โs  birth  parents  have  already been 
21 terminated bythe state court properlyhaving jurisdiction over the matter. Babygirl A.D., 
22 on information and belief, has more than 50% non-Indian blood.
23 10.  Plaintiff C.C. is a citizen of the United States and the State of Arizona, and 
24 domiciled in the State of Arizona. Baby boy C.C. is 5 years old. Baby boy C.C is an 
25 enrolled member of the Navajo Nation, a federally-recognized tribe. Parental rights of 
26 C.C.โs birth parents were terminated by the state court properly having jurisdiction over 
27 the matter. Adoption of C.C. by M.C. and K.C. was finalized by the state court properly 
28
3of 35

 
Case 2:15-cv-01259-NVW   Document 173   Filed 04/05/16   Page 4 of 108
1  having jurisdiction over the matter in November, 2015. Baby boy C.C., on information 
 
2  and belief, has more than 50% Hispanic blood. 
 
3    11.  Plaintiff L.G. is a citizen of the United States and of the State of Arizona, 
 
4  and domiciled in the State of Arizona.  Baby girl L.G. is approximately 3.5 years old.  
 
5  Baby girl L.G., on information and belief, is not eligible for membership in the Pascua 
 
6  Yaqui Tribe of Arizona, a federally-recognized tribe.  Parental rights of L.G.โs birth 
 
7  parents have not been terminated by the state court properly having jurisdiction over the 
 
8  matter.  Baby girl L.G., on information and belief, has more than 50% non-Indian blood. 
 
9    12.  Plaintiff C.R., baby girl L.G.โs half-sibling, is a citizen of the United States 
 
10  and of the State of Arizona, and domiciled in the State of Arizona. Baby boy C.R. is 
 
11  approximately 1.5 years old. Baby boy C.R., on information and belief, is eligible for 
 
12  membership in and is a child of a member of, or is already an enrolled member of, the 
 
13  Gila River Indian Community, a federally-recognized tribe. Parental rights of C.R.โs birth 
 
14  parents have not been terminated by the state court properly having jurisdiction over the 
 
15  matter. Baby boy C.R., on information and belief, has more than 50% non-Indian blood.    
 
16    13.   Carol Coghlan Carter is a citizen of the United States and the State of 
 
17  Arizona, and domiciled in the State of Arizona. She is an attorney licensed to practice in 
 
18  the State of Arizona. She has practiced in the area of family law for several decades. In 
 
19  the course of her legal career, she has represented during all stages of child custody 
 
20  proceedings children, including children with Indian ancestry as their court-appointed 
 
21  guardian-ad-litem;  birth  parents,  including  birth  parents  with  Indian  ancestry;  and 
 
22  foster/adoptive parents, including foster/adoptive parents with Indian ancestry and those 
 
23  in child custody proceedings involving children with Indian ancestry. She is โnext friendโ 
 
24  to baby girl A.D., baby boy C.C., baby girl L.G., and baby boy C.R., and all off-reservation 
 
25  children with Indian ancestry in the State of Arizona in child custody proceedings. See 
 
26  FRCP 17(c). 
 
27    14.  Dr. Ronald Federici is a citizen of the United States and the State of Virginia, 
 
28  and domiciled in the State of Virginia. He is a clinical neuropsychologist and clinical 
 
4 of 35 

Case 2:15-cv-01259-NVW   Document 173   Filed 04/05/16   Page 5 of 108
1 psychopharmacologist.  He  has  over  two  decades  of  experience  completing  complex 
2 neuropsychiatric evaluations of adults and children. He is a professional consultant to 
3 physicians, schools, mental health clinics, pediatric and adolescent medicine clinics. He 
4 has served as an expert witness in child custodyproceedings throughout the United States 
5 and abroad. He conducts training and education in Clinical Neuropsychology throughout 
6 the United States, and in Europe, Eastern Europe, United Kingdom, Australia, Canada, 
7 Iceland, and China. He serves as President of the Care for Children International, Inc., 
8 which is a humanitarian aid organization providing medical care, supplies, training and 
9 education to the Romanian Department of Child Protective Services. A short documentary 
10 on  Dr.  Federiciโs  work  in  Romania  is  available  at 
11 https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AC37HlWlP1I(last visited February18, 2016). He is 
12 โnext friendโ to babygirl A.D., babyboyC.C., babygirl L.G., and babyboyC.R., and all 
13 off-reservation children with Indian ancestry in the State of Arizona in child custody 
14 proceedings. See FRCP 17(c).
15 15.  Plaintiffs S.H. and J.H. are foster/preadoptive parents of baby girl A.D. 
16 Plaintiffs S.H. and J.H., a married couple, are both citizens of the United States and the 
17 State of Arizona, and are residents of and are domiciled in the State of Arizona. Neither 
18 S.H. nor J.H. are enrolled members of a tribe or eligible for membership in an Indian tribe. 
19 S.H. and J.H. are the only family baby girl A.D. has ever known as she was placed in 
20 foster care with them since her birth. Their petition to adopt baby girl A.D. is pending 
21 before the state court properlyhaving jurisdiction over the matter.
22 16.  Plaintiffs M.C. and K.C., a married couple, are both citizens of the United 
23 States and the State of Arizona, and are residents of and are domiciled in the State of 
24 Arizona. Neither M.C. nor K.C. are enrolled members of a tribe or eligible for membership 
25 in an Indian tribe. M.C. and K.C. were foster parents to baby boy C.C. for approximately 
26 four years. M.C. and K.C. adopted babyboyC.C. in November, 2015.
27 17. Plaintiffs K.R. and P.R. are foster parents of baby girl L.G. and baby boy 
28 C.R. Plaintiffs K.R. and P.R., a married couple, are both citizens of the United States and 
5of 35

Case 2:15-cv-01259-NVW   Document 173   Filed 04/05/16   Page 6 of 108
1 the State of Arizona, and are residents ofand are domiciled in the State of Arizona. Neither 
2 K.R. nor P.R. are enrolled members of a tribe or eligible for membership in an Indian 
3 tribe. K.R. and P.R. are the only family baby boy C.R. has ever known as he was placed 
4 in foster care with them since birth. K.R. and P.R. have been foster parents to baby girl 
5 L.G. and baby boy C.R. for approximately 1.5 years and want to adopt L.G. and C.R.
6 18.  Defendant Kevin Washburn is the Assistant Secretary of Indian Affairs of 
7 the Bureau of Indian Affairs (โBIAโ). He has primary authorityto enforce ICWA and the 
8 BIA Guidelines at issue. He is sued in his official capacity only.
9 19.  Defendant  Sally Jewell  is  the  Secretary of  the  Interior,  United  States 
10 Department of the Interior. The Department of the Interior is the cabinet agencyof which
11 BIA is a part and which is assigned enforcement powers under ICWA and Title 25 of 
12 United States Code. She is sued in her official capacityonly.
13 20.  Defendant GregoryA. McKay is the Director of the Arizona Department of 
14 Child Safety (โDCSโ). The Director has statutory duty under Ariz. Rev. Stat. (โA.R.S.โ) 
15 ยง 8-451 et seq. to โprotect children.โ The Director is also required to โ[e]nsure the 
16 departmentโs compliance with the Indian child welfare act of 1978 (P.L. 95-608; 92 Stat. 
17 3069; 25 United States Code ยงยง 1901 through 1963).โ A.R.S. ยง 8-453(A)(20). He is sued 
18 in his official capacity only.
19 FACTS COMMON TO ALL CLAIMS
20 I.  Baby Girl A.D.
21 21.  DCS tookbabygirl A.D. into protective custodyat birth as she was severely 
22 drug-exposed due to her biological motherโs ingestion of several controlled substances, 
23 and placed her with S.H. and J.H. They have taken care of baby girl A.D. ever since, and 
24 although she has some developmental delays due to her exposure to controlled substances,

11 I.  Definitions
12 59.  ICWA defines โIndian childโ as โany unmarried person who is under age 
13 eighteen and is either (a) a member of an Indian tribe or (b) is eligible for membership in 
14 an Indian tribe and is the biological child of a member of an Indian tribeโ 25 U.S.C. ยง 
15 1903(4). โIndian tribeโ is also statutorily defined at 25 U.S.C. ยง 1903(8).
16 60.  Most Indian tribes have only blood quantum or lineage requirements as 
17 prerequisites for membership. See Miss. Band of Choctaw Indians Const. art. III, ยง 1; 
18 Cherokee Nation Const. art. IV, ยง 1; Choctaw Nation of Okla. Const. art. II, ยง 1; Muscogee 
19 (Creek) Nation Const. art. III, ยง 2; Gila River Indian Community Const. art. III, ยง 1; 
20 Navajo Nation Code ยง 701; Guidelines for State Courts and Agencies in Indian Child 
21 Custody  Proceedings,  80  Fed.  Reg.  10146, 10153,  B.3  (February 25,  2015)  (โNew 
22 Guidelinesโ or โBIA Guidelinesโ). Consequently, ICWAโs definition of โIndian childโ is 
23 based solely on the childโs race or ancestry.
24 61.  Some of the tribes consider individuals with onlya tinypercentage of Indian 
25 blood to be Indian, even if they have little or no contact or connection with the tribe. See, 
26 e.g., Cherokee Nation Const. art. IV, ยง 1.
27 62.  Thus, in many instances, children with only a minute quantum of Indian 
28 blood and no connection or ties to the tribe are subject to ICWA and relegated to the tribeโs

7 II.  BIA Guidelines
8 71.  The BIA first issued Guidelines in November of 1979. Guidelines for State 
9 Courts; Indian Child Custody Proceedings, 44 Fed. Reg. 67584 (November 26, 1979) 
10 (โOld Guidelinesโ or โ1979 Guidelinesโ). On February 25, 2015, the BIA issued new 
11 Guidelines to โsupersede and replaceโ the 1979 Guidelines. Guidelines for State Courts 
12 and Agencies in Indian Child CustodyProceedings, 80 Fed. Reg. 10146, 10147 (February 
13 25, 2015) (โNew Guidelinesโ, โ2015 Guidelinesโ, or โBIA Guidelinesโ).
14 III.  The Jurisdiction-Transfer Provision
15 72.  ICWA  requires  state  courts  to  โtransferโ  โfoster  care  placementโ  or 
16 โtermination of parental rightsโ โproceeding[s] to the jurisdiction of the tribeโ of โan 
17 Indian child not domiciled or residing within the reservation of the Indian childโs tribeโ 
18 โin the absence of good cause to the contrary,โ and โabsent objection byeither parent,โ if 
19 the โparent or the Indian custodian or the Indian childโs tribeโ petitions for such transfer 
20 and the tribal court does not decline such transfer. 25 U.S.C. ยง 1911(b) (โjurisdiction-
21 transfer provisionโ); 80 Fed. Reg. at 10156, C.2. The New Guidelines, however, state, 
22 โThe right to request a transfer is available at any stage of an Indian child custody 
23 proceeding, including during any period of emergency removal.โ 80 Fed. Reg. at 10156, 
24 C.1(c) (emphasis added).
25 73.  Whereas ICWAโs jurisdiction-transfer provision is available to transfer only 
26 foster care placement and termination of parental rights proceedings to the jurisdiction of 
27 the tribe, the BIA, in the New Guidelines, extended the jurisdiction-transfer provision to 
28 all child custodyproceedings.

Child Welfare Reporting Requirements                                    April 1, 2015 - September 30, 2015 
 
Executive Summary 
 
The Arizona Department of Child Safety (DCS) is pleased to publish this semi-annual report for 
April 2015 through September 2015 in compliance with A.R.S. ยง 8-526.  In May 2014, the 
Department of Child Safety was created as a permanent, stand-alone agency with the express 
mission of safeguarding Arizonaโs abused and neglected children.  
 
The data within this Semi-Annual Report assists with identifying areas for continued focus by 
the Department, stakeholders, policy makers, and advocacy groups. By working collaboratively 
toward shared goals, targeted resources and strategies will be implemented in a coordinated and 
purposeful manner, improving safety, permanency and well-being outcomes for children and 
families. 
 
Child Abuse Hotline and Investigations 
 
The statewide Child Abuse Hotline received 26,455 calls that met the statutory criteria for a report.  
Of these, 433 were within the jurisdiction of military or tribal governments and were referred to 
those jurisdictions. The total number of reports represents a four percent increase over the prior 
reporting  period,  and  a  5.5  percent  increase  over  the  same  reporting  period  last  year.    The 
Department continues to experience an increase in neglect reports, while the other maltreatment 
types have remained steady.  
 
In addition to responding to all reports received in this reporting period, the Department closed 
more reports (15,076) this reporting period than any other reporting period in the past four years.  
This was accomplished even though DCS received more reports than it did in any other reporting 
period in the last four years.  This total number of reports closed is limited to reports that were 
received during the reporting period and subsequently closed.  Reports that were received in 
prior reporting periods and closed within this reporting period are not included in this total. 
 
The DCS Strategic Plan was announced in July 2015 and identified several goals with deliverables 
for the Hotline and investigations.  To date, the Department has completed several deliverables, 
including, but not limited to: 
   
โข  Instituted notification to callers to the Hotline about false reporting penalties; 
โข  Hired dedicated audit staff at the Hotline for quality assurance; 
โข  Completed policy analysis on the investigation/assessment of very low risk families; 
โข  Created a new Hotline screening decision-making tool that clarifies report and 
prioritization requirements; 
โข  Implemented a field guide that facilitates the collection and documentation of safety and 
risk assessment information; 
โข  Created and implemented supervision guides for investigation and ongoing cases; 
โข  Created a review guide for Assistant Program Managers aligned with the safety; 
assessment model for use in considered removals; 
โข  Implemented Multidisciplinary Team (MDT) reviews of fatality/near fatality cases;  
โข  Created a data dashboard to monitor open report volume and categorize reports by risk 
factors; and 
โข  Created a dashboard to track overall investigation case management.

Children in Out-of-Home Care 
 
The Department remains committed to working with the community to keep children safe and 
prevent  the  need  for  children  to  be  removed  from  their  homes.  Notwithstanding  this 
commitment, the number of children in out-of-home care increased from 17,592 in the prior 
reporting period to 18,657 in September 2015.  
 
The Department continues to make efforts to place children who have been removed from their 
home  in  the  most  family-like  setting  possible.  In  September  2015,  14,863  children  โ  or 
approximately 80 percent of all children in out-of-home care โ were placed with relatives, licensed 
foster parents, or trial home visit with a parent.  Efforts to increase the number of licensed foster 
parents who are able to meet the needs of children requiring out-of-home placement resulted in 774 
new homes being licensed during the reporting period.     
 
As part of the strategic plan, the Department is striving to improve capacity to place children in 
family environments and fully meet the needs of children in care and their families.  During this 
reporting period DCS was able to accomplish the following: 
 
โข  Increased use of Placement Coordinators to identify available kinship placements upon 
removal; 
โข  Expanded the use of software tools, e.g. Lexis Nexis, to find potential kinship placements;  
โข  Established Fostering Inclusion Respect Support Trust Advisory (FIRST) Commission; and 
โข  Established the Building Resilient Families program to deliver in-home prevention services 
in Maricopa County for low risk families who have been the subject of a DCS investigation. 
 
The state requires monthly face-to-face visitation with children in foster care.  The current report 
shows that 84.4 percent of the children in foster care received their visitation during the last month 
of the reporting period. There is a strong correlation between caseworker visits with children and 
positive outcomes for these children, such as achieving permanency and other indicators of child 
well-being.  The Department continues to make efforts to improve our rate of visitation. 
 
Permanency for Children 
 
Arizona  is  a  national  leader  in  the  number  of  finalized  adoptions.  The  Department  remains 
committed to work toward achieving permanency for children placed in out-of-home care as 
demonstrated by increasing the total number of children achieving permanency through adoption. 
This number increased by two percent, from 1,576 during this reporting period compared to 1,552 
during the same reporting period last year.   
 
The Department demonstrated a significant increase in the number of children safely reunified with 
their  families.    3,102  children  exited  DCS  custody  to  reunify  with  their  parents  or  primary 
caretakers this reporting period compared to 2,636 during the last reporting period, which is an 18% 
increase. 
 
As part of the Strategic Plan, the Department continues recruitment efforts of foster and adoptive 
homes.   Recently, the Department adjusted foster care reimbursement rates for families who are

willing and capable of providing a home for youth ages 12 to 18 years old and sibling groups in this

Strategic Goals to Address Challenges 
 
The Department continues to face both workload and process challenges in its efforts to ensure 
safety and promote permanency for abused and neglected children. Examples of the more pressing 
challenges the Department continues to pursue include the increased number of children in out-of-
home care, the significant amount of overdue investigations, and the need to improve the hiring and 
training  of  qualified  personnel.    The  Departmentโs  Strategic  Plan  represents  the  leadershipโs 
commitment to refocus attention and resources on the safety, permanency, and well-being of 
children in Arizona.  Below are five strategic goals that address several of the most pressing 
challenges faced by the Department:  
 
1.  Improve objective decision-making at the Hotline and investigations. 
2.  Improve performance and quality of service through employee retention. 
3.  Reduce length of stay for children in out-of-home care. 
4.  Reduce recurrence of maltreatment by improving service delivery. 
5.  Improve capacity to place children in family environments. 
 
As noted previously, the legislation enacted to create the Department included funding to increase 
the number of child safety specialists. Hiring these specialists during fiscal year 2015 presented a 
significant challenge to the Department.  However, in September 2015 the Department had filled 
nearly all of its budgeted positions for child safety specialists, including staff at the Hotline.   
 
The Department continues to assess processes and program controls to identify ways to address 
these challenges. Solutions will include partnering with the community and stakeholders to ensure 
that the safety and wellbeing of the children is always the top priority.  The Department continues to 
work in partnership with the federal government to meet the federal Child and Family Service 
Review (CFSR) standards to improve outcomes for the children and families it serves. 
 
The Department previously included three charts that were not required by A.R.S. ยง 8-526.  In 
order to better align this report with the requirements of the statute, the Department is not 
including these charts anymore.  Information on the number of children in care by placement 
type and by age is still included in Table 33 of this report.

Reports of Child Abuse & Neglect 
 
Child abuse and neglect are defined in A.R.S. ยง 8-201 and A.R.S. ยง 13-3623 (A).  These definitions provide 
the major categories in this report. 
 
Between April 1, 2015 through September 30, 2015, there were 26,455 incoming communications to the 
Child Abuse Hotline that met the criteria for a report of abuse or neglect. Of these, 433 were within the 
jurisdiction of military or tribal governments and were referred to those jurisdictions. Compared to one 
year ago, there has been a 5.5 percent increase in reports received by the Child Abuse Hotline meeting the 
criteria of a report of abuse or neglect. 
 
Table 1 shows the number of reports received by the Department by category of maltreatment for the 
current and past reporting periods. One consistent trend is the increase in the proportion of reports that 
meet the criteria of neglect. In accordance with Strategic Plan, the Department is examining current Child 
Abuse Hotline policies and procedures to improve objectivity within screening tools and improve inter-
rater reliability.

Chart 3 below provides information on the number of reports that met each of the Centralized Intake 
Hotline priority classifications in the current and past reporting periods. In Table 2 and Table 3, data on 
total reports by priority is shown by county for the current and previous reporting periods. The priority 
determinations are made by personnel at the child abuse hotline after the review of multiple factors, 
however, below is a high level summary of each response time criteria.   
 
PRIORITY 1: Present danger refers to an immediate, significant and clearly observable family 
condition present now that has resulted in or is likely to result in serious or severe harm requiring 
an immediate initial response. 
 
PRIORITY 2: Impending danger may not be occurring in the present but is likely to occur in the 
immediate to near future and will likely result in serious or severe harm to a child. 
 
PRIORITY 3: Reports that do not rise to the level of present or impending danger, but there is an 
incident of abuse or neglect that has happened in the past 30 days. This includes a current minor 
injury to the child. 
 
PRIORITY 4: Reports that do not rise to the level of present or impending danger, but 1) there is 
an incident of abuse or neglect that happened more than 30 days ago, or 2) the date of last 
occurrence is unknown and there is no current physical indicator of maltreatment, or 3) there is 
unreasonable risk of harm to the childโs health or welfare.

ASSIGNMENT OF INVESTIGATIONS 
 
During the current reporting period, there were 26,455 calls to the Hotline that met the statutory criteria 
for a report. Of those, 433 reports fell within the jurisdiction of military or tribal governments. All reports 
had response data entered at the time this report was compiled. The assignment of the remaining 26,022 
reports for investigation is report in this section. 
 
The tables and charts in this section provide statewide and county level information on these reports 
assigned to DCS. Of these, DCS completed 15,076 (57.9%) of their assigned investigations. Those not 
completed remain open when the investigation is still in process, when the specialist is waiting for the 
results of a law enforcement investigation and/or receipt of records that impact the investigation finding, 
or when the investigation has been completed but is awaiting supervisory review and approval.

COMPLETED INVESTIGATIONS 
 
Substantiated reports are reports where the Department has determined that at least one of the allegations 
in the report of abuse and/or neglect is true.  The number of reports that are considered substantiated are a 
subset of the total number of reports that were received, investigated, and closed during the reporting 
period. 
 
The preliminary number of reports that are substantiated for the current reporting period is 1,926.  For the 
prior  reporting  period,  the  number  of  reports  that  were  assigned  for  investigation  that  resulted  in 
substantiated findings was revised from 1,606 to 3,535.  This number will change each reporting period as 
a result of subsequent decisions based on parentsโ rights to due process as well as the completion of 
investigations and findings.   
 
โข  The  preliminary  substantiation  rate  for  the  current  reporting  period  is  7%.  However,  the 
substantiation rate for the current period is anticipated to be revised upwards in the next semi-
annual report. 
 
โข  The substantiation rate for the prior reporting period is 14%. However, when initially reported, 
the September 2014 โ March 2015 substantiation rate was 6%.

SAFE HAVEN INFANTS 
 
Communications from providers indicate that there were no newborn infants delivered to Safe Haven 
providers during the April 2015 โ September 2015 reporting period. This compares to two infants being 
delivered to Safe Haven providers during the prior reporting period. 
 
CHILDREN ENTERING OUT-OF-HOME CARE 
 
During the current reporting period, 6,819 children entered care, which represents a 14.9% increase in 
children entering care over the prior reporting period and a 5.5% increase over the same reporting period 
last year. As can be seen from Chart 18 below, the increasing trend of children entering out-of-home care 
continues. This increase in the number of children entering care is not unexpected as the number of 
reports of abuse and neglect has continued to increase (see Chart 1 for number of reports detail). It is 
important to note, however, that child welfare data is seasonal.  The trend in the data shows a higher 
number of reports and therefore a higher number children entering out-of-home care in reporting periods 
that cover April through September.  This seasonality can be attributed to higher call volume to the 
Hotline in April, Child Abuse Awareness month, and the close and start of the school year in May and 
August, respectively.

CHILDREN ENTERING OUT-OF-HOME CARE โ VOLUNTARY SERVICES 
 
The number of children entering out-of-home placement through voluntary foster care agreements for the 
current reporting period was 154, which represents 2.3 percent of the children entering care this reporting 
period. Information on the county level distribution of voluntary placements into out-of-home care can be 
found in Table 29 for the current reporting period and in Table 30 for the prior reporting period. 
 
Voluntary foster care may be provided when the parents or legal guardians of a child have requested such 
assistance and have signed a legally binding written agreement for the temporary placement of the child 
in foster care while risk factors are addressed to enable the child to live safely at home.  A.R.S. ยง 8-806 
authorizes the Department to provide voluntary foster care placement for children for a period not to 
exceed 90 days and no more than twice within 24 consecutive months.

FOSTER HOME LICENSING, CLOSURES, & VISITATION 
 
As of September 30, 2015, there were 4,5519 foster homes licensed for a total capacity of 9,114 spaces.  
Of the spaces, 2,431 are reported by contractors to be unavailable for placements. Reasons for this 
include,  but  are  not  limited  to,  licensing  restrictions  on  age,  bed  holds  for  youth  in  treatment  or 
hospitalization, foster parents' need for temporary reprieve from placements and corrective action plans.  
In addition, 975 spaces in available foster homes were unused spaces. This occurs when a match between 
the available spaces and childrenโs needs was not possible.  Unused spaces may be, but are not limited to, 
the result of a denial by foster parents and/or contractors to the Department's request for placement due to 
the severity of child's needs, potential risk to other children in the home, the distance of a foster home 
from child's family and/or lack of unique services in the foster home's vicinity. 
 
Licensed foster homes include family foster homes, professional family foster homes (HCTC homes), 
respite foster homes, receiving foster homes, and developmentally disabled homes with DCS children 
placed in them. Foster home licenses specify the age range, gender and maximum number of children that 
can be placed in a home. Foster parents, in consultation with the licensing worker, decide the type of 
physical, behavioral, and psychological needs of children they can effectively parent based upon their 
own skill level, experiences, and desires. 
 
During the current reporting period, 774 new homes were licensed to provide foster care and 767 homes 
left the system. This compares to 821 new homes being licensed and 785 homes leaving the system 
during the prior reporting period. The following chart gives the reasons for foster home closures for the 
current reporting period.

maltreatment deaths reported on the website by the Arizona Department of Health Services (ADHS). 
  
โข  DCS posts information in accordance with A.R.S. ยง 8-807 on child fatalities due to abuse or neglect 
by the childโs parent, custodian or caregiver at: https://dcs.az.gov/news/child-fatalities-near-fatalities-
information-releases.    
โข  This information is posted when the information comes to DCS's attention and a final determination 
of the fatality due to abuse or neglect has been made by either a substantiated finding or specific 
criminal charges filed against a parent, guardian or caregiver for causing the fatality.  
โข  The information that comes to DCS's attention and the determination of the fatality due to abuse or 
neglect  may  occur  sometime  after  the  actual  incident  for  a  number  of  reasons  including  a

documents.text:
Case 2:15-cv-01259-NVW   Document 244   Filed 03/16/17   Page 1 of 20
 
 
 
1  WO 
2   
3   
4   
5   
6  IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
7  FOR THE DISTRICT OF ARIZONA 
 
8 
 
9  A.D.,  C.C.,  L.G.,  and  C.R.,  by  Carol  No. CV-15-01259-PHX-NVW
Coghlan  Carter,  and  Dr.  Ronald  Federici,   
10  their next friends; S.H. and J.H., a married  ORDER 
couple;  M.C.  and  K.C.,  a  married  couple;   
11  K.R.  and  P.R.,  a  married  couple;  for 
themselves  and  on  behalf  of  a  class  of 
12  similarly-situated individuals, 
 
13  Plaintiffs, 
 
14  v.  
 
15  Kevin Washburn, in his official capacity as 
Assistant Secretary of Indian Affairs, 
16  Bureau of Indian Affairs; Sally Jewell, in 
her official capacity as Secretary of the 
17 
Interior, U. S. Department of the Interior; 
Gregory A. McKay, in his official capacity 
18 
as Director of Arizona Department of Child 
Safety, 
19 
 
Defendants, 
20 
 
Gila River Indian Community and the 
21 
Navajo Nation, 
 
22 
Intervenor Defendants.
23 
 
 
24 
Before the Court are motions to dismiss the First Amended Complaint by the 
25 
Federal Defendants (Doc. 178) and the State Defendant (Doc. 179), the Responses, and 
26 
the Replies.  Also before the Court are motions to dismiss the First Amended Complaint 
27 
by the Intervenor-Defendants Gila River Indian Community (Doc. 217) and the Navajo 
28 
 

 
Case 2:15-cv-01259-NVW   Document 244   Filed 03/16/17   Page 2 of 20
 
 
 
1  Nation (Doc. 218), the response, and the replies.  Amicus curiae briefs have been filed in 
2  support of and in opposition to the motions to dismiss. 
3  In this action the adult Plaintiffs and those who have undertaken to speak for the 
4  child Plaintiffs attempt to challenge parts of the Indian Child Welfare Act (โICWAโ) as 
5  unconstitutional racial discrimination.  They also challenge Congressโs power to enact 
6  laws regulating state court proceedings and ousting state laws concerning foster care 
7  placement,  termination  of  parental  rights,  preadoptive  placement,  and  adoptive 
8  placements of some off-reservation children of Indian descent.  More specifically, these 
9  are children whose parents elected to leave Indian Country and take up residence off 
10  reservation with the benefits of and obligations under state law of all other persons within 
11  the jurisdiction of the state and outside Indian Country.   
12  Plaintiffs seek a declaration that certain provisions of the Indian Child Welfare Act 
13  and of the Guidelines for State Courts and Agencies in Indian Child Custody Proceedings 
14  published on February 25, 2015 (โ2015 Guidelinesโ)1 by the Department of the Interior, 
15  Bureau of Indian Affairs (โBIAโ), violate the United States Constitution, federal civil 
16  rights statutes, and Title VI of the Civil Rights Act by requiring State courts to treat 
17  Indian children differently than non-Indian children in child custody proceedings.  They 
18  seek to enjoin the Federal Defendants from enforcing these provisions and the State 
19  Defendant from complying with and enforcing these provisions.  The Guidelines do not 
20  have the force of law.  They might be viewed uncharitably as avoiding the rule-making 
21  requirements of the Administrative Procedures Act but still having enough of the look of 
22  regulations that judges and others will follow them anyway. 
23  In ICWA, adopted in 1978, Congress responded to the increasing adoption by non-
24  Indian families of Indian children resident off-reservation and subject to the exclusive 
25  jurisdiction of state courts.  Congress enacted ICWA: 
26  . . . to protect the best interests of Indian children and to promote the 
stability and security of Indian tribes and families by the establishment of 
27 
                                              
28  1  80  Fed.  Reg.  10146โ10159  (Feb.  25,  2015)  (superseding  and  replacing  the 
guidelines published at 44 Fed. Reg. 67584โ67595 (Nov. 28, 1979)).   
 
- 2 - 

 
Case 2:15-cv-01259-NVW   Document 244   Filed 03/16/17   Page 3 of 20
 
 
 
1  minimum Federal standards for the removal of Indian children from their 
families and the placement of such children in foster or adoptive homes 
2 
which will reflect the unique values of Indian culture, and by providing for 
3  assistance  to  Indian  tribes  in  the  operation  of  child  and  family  service 
programs. 
4 
25 U.S.C. ยง 1902.   
5 
From the outset Plaintiffs have grounded sweeping challenges to ICWA and the 
6 
2015 Guidelines on vague or narrow allegations of their own experience with ICWA.  
7 
The motions to dismiss probe the jurisdictional specifics of each Plaintiffโs allegations. 
8 
I.  REGULATORY BACKGROUND 
9 
Congress authorized the Department of the Interior to make rules and regulations 
10 
necessary for carrying out provisions of ICWA.  25 U.S.C. ยง 1952.  The Department 
11 
promulgated regulations to govern funding and administering Indian child and family 
12 
service programs as authorized by ICWA.  25 C.F.R. ยง 23.1.  The regulations also 
13 
addressed notice procedures for involuntary child custody proceedings involving Indian 
14 
children, but they โdid not address the specific requirements and standards that ICWA 
15 
imposes  upon  State  court  child  custody  proceedings,  beyond  the  requirements  for 
16 
contents of the notice.โ  80 Fed. Reg. 10146, 10147.  To supplement the regulations, the 
17 
Department published guidelines for State courts to use in interpreting many of ICWAโs 
18 
requirements in Indian child custody proceedings.  Id.  In 2015, the Department published 
19 
the updated 2015 Guidelines to supersede and replace the guidelines published in 1979.  
20 
Id.  Like the previous guidelines, the 2015 Guidelines are not tethered to regulations. 
21 
The 2015 Guidelines โprovide standard procedures and best practices to be used in 
22 
Indian child welfare proceedings in State courts.โ  80 Fed. Reg. 10146, 10147.  They 
23

1  In June 2016, the Department added a new subpart to its regulations implementing 
2  ICWA, which โaddresses requirements for State courts in ensuring implementation of 
3  ICWA  in  Indian  child-welfare  proceedings  and  requirements  for  States  to  maintain 
4  records under ICWA.โ  81 Fed. Reg. 38778, 38778 (June 14, 2016).  The regulations in 
5  the new subpart โclarify the minimum Federal standards governing implementation of 
6  [ICWA] to ensure that ICWA is applied in all States consistent with the Actโs express 
7  language, Congressโs intent in enacting the statute, and to promote the stability and 
8  security of Indian tribes and families.โ  25 C.F.R. ยง 23.101. 
9  The new subpart became effective on December 12, 2016.  None of the provisions 
10  of  the  new  subpart  affects  a  proceeding  under  State  law  that  was  initiated  before 
11  December 12, 2016, but the provisions of the new subpart do apply to any subsequent 
12  proceeding in the same matter or affecting the custody or placement of the same child.  
13  23 C.F.R. ยง 23.143.  For example, the new subpart does not apply to a foster care 
14  placement  proceeding  initiated  in  November  2016,  but  it  does  apply  to  an  adoptive 
15  placement proceeding initiated in January 2017 for the same child. 
16  In conjunction with the new subpart of ICWA regulations, on December 12, 2016, 
17  the Department published Guidelines for Implementing the Indian Child Welfare Act 
18  (โ2016 Guidelinesโ), which replaced the 1979 and 2015 versions.  Under each heading, 
19  the  2016  Guidelines  provide  the  text  of  the  regulation  (if  there  is  one),  guidance, 
20  recommended practices, and suggestions for implementation.   
21  The  Amended  Complaint  does  not  challenge  any  regulations  or  the  2016 
22  Guidelines.  It challenges only certain provisions of ICWA and the 2015 Guidelines.

18  III.  LEGAL STANDARD 
19  On  a  motion  to  dismiss  under  Federal  Rule  of  Civil  Procedure  12(b)(6),  all 
20  allegations  of  material  fact  are  assumed  to  be  true  and  construed  in  the  light  most 
21  favorable to the nonmoving party.  Cousins v. Lockyer, 568 F.3d 1063, 1067 (9th Cir. 
22  2009).  To avoid dismissal, a complaint need contain only โenough facts to state a claim 
23  for relief that is plausible on its face.โ  Bell Atl. Corp. v. Twombly, 550 U.S. 544, 570 
24  (2007).  The principle that a court accepts as true all of the allegations in a complaint 
25  does not apply to legal conclusions or conclusory factual allegations.  Ashcroft v. Iqbal, 
26  556 U.S. 662, 678 (2009).   
27  Under  Rule  12(b)(1),  a  defendant  may  challenge  the  plaintiffโs  jurisdictional 
28  allegations by either (1) attacking the plaintiffโs allegations as insufficient on their face to 
 
- 7 - 

 
Case 2:15-cv-01259-NVW   Document 244   Filed 03/16/17   Page 8 of 20
 
 
 
1  invoke federal jurisdiction or (2) contesting the truth of the plaintiffโs factual allegations, 
2  usually by introducing evidence outside the pleadings.  Leite v. Crane Co., 749 F.3d 
3  1117, 1121 (9th Cir. 2014).  The first, a facial attack, is resolved by the district court as it 
4  would  be  under  Rule  12(b)(6),  i.e.,  accepting  the  plaintiffโs  allegations  as  true  and 
5  drawing all reasonable inferences in the plaintiffโs favor, the court determines whether 
6  the allegations are legally sufficient to invoke the courtโs jurisdiction.  Id.  The second, a 
7  factual  attack,  requires  the  plaintiff  to  support  its  jurisdictional  allegations  with 
8  competent proof, under the same evidentiary standard applied on summary judgment.  
9  Thus, the plaintiff bears the burden of proving by a preponderance of the evidence that 
10  each of the requirements for subject matter jurisdiction has been met.  Id.   
11  IV.  STANDING 
12  A.  Requirements for Article III Standing 
โA  suit  brought  by  a  plaintiff  without  Article  III  standing  is  not  a  โcase  or 
13 
controversy,โ and an Article III federal court therefore lacks subject matter jurisdiction 
14 
over the suit.โ  Braunstein v. Arizona Depโt of Transp., 683 F.3d 1177, 1184 (9th Cir. 
15 
2012).  โStanding must be shown with respect to each form of relief sought, whether it be 
16 
injunctive relief, damages or civil penalties.โ  Bates v. United Parcel Serv., Inc., 511 F.3d 
17 
974, 985 (9th Cir. 2007) (citing Friends of the Earth, Inc. v. Laidlaw Envtl. Servs. (TOC), 
18 
Inc., 528 U.S. 167, 185 (2000)). 
19 
To satisfy Article III standing, a plaintiff must show: 
20 
(1) [he or she] has suffered an โinjury in factโ that is (a) concrete and 
21 
particularized and (b) actual or imminent, not conjectural or hypothetical; 
22 
(2) the injury is fairly traceable to the challenged action of the defendant; 
and (3) it is likely, as opposed to merely speculative, that the injury will be 
23 
redressed by a favorable decision.  
24 
Friends of the Earth, Inc. v. Laidlaw Envtl. Servs. (TOC), Inc., 528 U.S. 167, 180โ81 
25 
(2000).  โThe party invoking federal jurisdiction bears the burden of establishing these 
26 
elements.โ  Lujan v. Defenders of Wildlife, 504 U.S. 555, 561 (1992).   
27 
For an equal protection claim, a plaintiff may show an โinjury in factโ caused by 
28 
denial of equal treatment: 
 
- 8 - 

 
Case 2:15-cv-01259-NVW   Document 244   Filed 03/16/17   Page 9 of 20
 
 
 
1  When  the  government  erects  a  barrier  that  makes  it  more  difficult  for 
members of one group to obtain a benefit than it is for members of another 
2 
group, a member of the former group seeking to challenge the barrier need 
3  not allege that he would have obtained the benefit but for the barrier in 
order to establish standing.  The โinjury in factโ in an equal protection case 
4 
of this variety is the denial of equal treatment resulting from the imposition 
5  of the barrier, not the ultimate inability to obtain the benefit.  
6  Ne. Fla. Chapter, Associated Gen. Contractors of America v. Jacksonville, 508 U.S. 656, 
7  666 (1993).  โ[E]qual treatment under the law is a judicially cognizable interest that 
8  satisfies the case or controversy requirement of Article III, even if it brings no tangible 
9  benefit to the party asserting it.โ  Davis v. Guam, 785 F.3d 1311, 1316 (9th Cir. 2015) 
10  (citing Heckler v. Matthews, 465 U.S. 728, 739 (1984)).  โUnequal treatment is an injury 
11  even if curing the inequality has no tangible consequences.โ  Id.   
12  However,  even  in  the  equal  protection  context,  โa  plaintiff  must  assert  a 
13  particularized injury, rather than a generalized grievance.โ  Braunstein, 683 F.3d at 1185.  
14  โEven if the government has discriminated on the basis of race, only those who are 
15  โpersonally deniedโ equal treatment have a cognizable injury under Article III.โ  Id. 
16  (finding  plaintiff  had  not  provided  any  evidence  the  governmentโs  racial  preference 
17  program affected him personally or had impeded his ability to compete for work on an 
18  equal basis). 
19  Ordinarily,  the  existence  of  federal  jurisdiction  depends  on  the  facts  as  they 
20  existed when the complaint was filed.  Lujan, 504 U.S. at 569 n.4.

1  to request a transfer to tribal jurisdiction is available only in proceedings for foster care

24  Plaintiffs have not sought leave to further amend their complaint, and leave to do 
25  so will not be granted.  Although leave to amend a pleading should be freely given โwhen 
26  justice so requires,โ Fed. R. Civ. P. 15(a)(2), courts should consider five factors:  bad

1  faith, undue delay, prejudice to the opposing party, futility of amendment, and whether 
2  the plaintiff has previously amended the complaint.  Johnson v. Buckley, 356 F.3d 1067, 
3  1077 (9th Cir. 2004).  Courts have โespecially broadโ discretion to deny leave to amend 
4  where the plaintiff already has had one or more opportunities to amend a complaint.  
5  Ascon Props., Inc. v. Mobil Oil Co., 866 F.2d 1149, 1161 (9th Cir. 1989); Moore v. 
6  Kayport Package Exp., Inc., 885 F.2d 531, 538 (9th Cir. 1989) (โLeave to amend need 
7  not be given if a complaint, as amended, is subject to dismissal.โ).   
8  Plaintiffs  initiated  this  action  on  July  6,  2015,  alleging  a  putative  class  so 
9  numerous that joinder of all members is impracticable, but despite being granted leave to 
10  amend, they have not named any plaintiffs with standing to challenge any provisions of 
11  ICWA or the 2015 Guidelines.  Further leave to amend would cause undue delay and 
12  likely would be futile. 
13  The legal questions Plaintiffs wish to adjudicate here in advance of injury to 
14  themselves  will  be  automatically  remediable  for  anyone  actually  injured.    The  very 
15  allegations of wrongfulness are that such injuries will arise in state court child custody 
16  proceedings, directly in the court processes or in actions taken by state officers under the 
17  control and direction of judges in those proceedings.  Any true injury to any child or 
18  interested adult can be addressed in the state court proceeding itself, based on actual facts 
19  before the court, not on hypothetical concerns.  If any Plaintiffs encounter future real 
20  harm in their own proceedings, the judge in their own case can discern the rules of 
21  decision.  They do not have standing to have this Court pre-adjudicate for state court 
22  judges how to rule on facts that may arise and that may be governed by statutes or 
23  guidelines that this Court may think invalid.
